subject: RE: [junit] random testing with JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I appreciate the recent comments to my post, you all have given me good food for thought, and I am coming around to the test everything reproducibly
messageBody:
>One particular code smell I encounter frequently is when JUnit suites
>have lots (or any) System.out.println() statements. That normally
>indicates someone is trying to get more data out of JUnit tests than
>they're really intended to produce. It's even worse if these statements
>print when the tests are passing as well as failing. In this case,
>actual failures are likely to get swamped by the usual output and may
>well not be noticed, especially when running from Ant or the
>textui.TestRunner so there's no red bar. Honestly I think the standard
>Ant JUnit task produces too much output already. I only want to see
>tests that failed. I want line of output at most if all tests passed.
>
>--
>Elliotte Rusty Harold elharo@...


I appreciate the recent comments to my post, you all have given me good food
for thought, and I am coming around to the "test everything reproducibly"
point of view.

I confess that I have some System.out.println() statements in my test cases.
Partly it is to see which random cases were generated, and I see the point
that I shouldn't have to scan the output. However, at least I'm sure the
tests are running the way I think they should be running! I distrust
computers and software greatly, so I'm always trying to check up on what I
think is going on... this is doubly true when I'm using new (for me)
software like Junit.

How do you Junit veterans assure yourself that a test is actually running
and doing what it should be doing?

--ErikN
